Articles.Content:
6 hours ago, p1t1o said:

So why'd you buy the game? Blind trust? Or based on its track record?

I'm sorry, but what makes you think that these two situations are similar enough to compare without any change in approach? Legitimately, I want to understand the train of thought that landed here.

8 hours ago, Alshain said:

Hint: Quotes (" ") are used to quote statements, not make new statements on my behalf.  Even if it was something I said, quite frankly, you and many other players do not concern me.  I know that sounds selfish at first, but it's really just logical.  It is my desire to play the game myself, it is irrelevant to me that you can play.  What exactly are you expecting?  I can't play the game I bought, but hey RIC can play so that makes it all better?

If "hyperbole" now means proven track record, then you may be right.  But I'm pretty sure that is not the case.  So, what are you saying, I can't say 1.1 is broken because it doesn't matter now, I can't say 1.2 is going be broken because despite all historical evidence to the contrary, I don't know it will.  Exactly which version am I allowed to talk about according to you?

You know @Alshain does have a point. I can play the game fine with little issues here and there. It is what it is. But I have to agree with Alshain on this one. If it was your game that you paid for and it was unplayable for you and then you learned the devs are going to add new features before fixing bugs I think you would be a little PO'ed also because now you have to wait twice as long to play your game right? The patience wears even thinner then before when it was already thin to begin with. That being said i totally get where Alshain is coming from. But at the same time Alshain I would take a wait and see approach. Im pretty sure 1.1.2 will have some bug fixes in it not JUST new features. Patience man..I dont think you'll be disapointed. Squad just got back from a well deserved vacation...let them get settled in...big issues like you, and others i might add, are having I am sure will be addressed. Have confidence.

Edited May 25, 2016 by Redneck

12 minutes ago, Redneck said:

Im pretty sure 1.1.2 will have some bug fixes in it not JUST new features.

I'm pretty sure that 1.1.2 is the current release version.  It has been clearly stated that 1.1.3 will be a bug-fix patch and 1.2 is intended to contain a Unity engine upgrade, other bug fixes (that rely on the Unity upgrade) and some new features.  As far as I understand, new features will not be developed before 1.1.3 is released and only features that were originally planned for 1.1 and are already significantly far through implementation will be included in 1.2.

Edited May 25, 2016 by Padishar

2 minutes ago, Padishar said:

I'm pretty sure that 1.1.2 is the current release version.  It has been clearly stated that 1.1.3 will be a bug-fix patch and 1.2 is intended to contain a Unity engine upgrade, other bug fixes and some new features.  As far as I understand, new features will not be developed before 1.1.3 is released and only features that were originally planned for 1.1 and are already significantly far through implementation will be included in 1.2.

dang did i say 1.1.2? i sure did well to late to change it now i meant 1.1.3 thanks for correcting that

54 minutes ago, Andem said:

I'm sorry, but what makes you think that these two situations are similar enough to compare without any change in approach? Legitimately, I want to understand the train of thought that landed here.

I'm not sure I know what you're asking...I did have some point to make when I typed it, but its probably best let go at this point.
Imagine if SQUAD built their own engine and we never had to say the word 'Unity' again...dreams.

2 hours ago, Padishar said:

I'm pretty sure that 1.1.2 is the current release version.  It has been clearly stated that 1.1.3 will be a bug-fix patch and 1.2 is intended to contain a Unity engine upgrade, other bug fixes (that rely on the Unity upgrade) and some new features.  As far as I understand, new features will not be developed before 1.1.3 is released and only features that were originally planned for 1.1 and are already significantly far through implementation will be included in 1.2.

You understand entirely correctly.

1.1.3 will include those fixes we can do in a reasonable timeframe (i.e. that will not unreasonably delay the engine update that will do more fixes) and without prejudicing said update (i.e. doing tons of work we'd just have to rip out). 1.2 is first and foremost a Unity upgrade that should offer better hardware and OS support/fixes (i.e. less crashing) and better wheels/legs/etc support/fixes. Beyond that come any new (or partially-new) features.

I had thought the dev notes made clear those were our priorities, but let this serve as clarification.

45 minutes ago, NathanKell said:

You understand entirely correctly.

1.1.3 will include those fixes we can do in a reasonable timeframe (i.e. that will not unreasonably delay the engine update that will do more fixes) and without prejudicing said update (i.e. doing tons of work we'd just have to rip out). 1.2 is first and foremost a Unity upgrade that should offer better hardware and OS support/fixes (i.e. less crashing) and better wheels/legs/etc support/fixes. Beyond that come any new (or partially-new) features.

I had thought the dev notes made clear those were our priorities, but let this serve as clarification.

It's clear, people just read what they want to read, and can't be happy.  Thanks for the update and the continued work!  KSP continues to be the best game purchase I've made, and 1.1 has been the best performing version to date.  And new bugs have been outweighed considerably by new capabilities in my opinion.

52 minutes ago, NathanKell said:

1.2 is first and foremost a Unity upgrade that should offer better hardware and OS support/fixes (i.e. less crashing) and better wheels/legs/etc support/fixes.

Wasn't that the idea behind 1.1?

5 minutes ago, razark said:

Wasn't that the idea behind 1.1?

The road to hell is paved with good intentions. Sometimes things don't work out the way you envision them.
@Alshain are you a Linux player?

Sorry, but if the current unity version is incompatible with landing a spacecraft (I don't ever use aircraft/spaceplanes, but for those people it sounds worse than my legged landers), then 1.1.2 should be "pre-release" and not released until that is fixed.

I was unable to participate in the steam pre-release (no steam), but had this been just an open pre-release, I'd not be complaining, I'd be posting bug reports and testing. Since they bothered to call it a release, I'm complaining since the exploding legs and apparently gear is a total show-stopper. 'Do whatever you like as long as you never touch the ground anyplace, or EVA on orbit near any craft with legs!"

On 24/05/2016 at 6:48 AM, 0111narwhalz said:

And you guys make up for the weeks of silence with an early devnote. 

Posted 6am Wednesday for some of us. 

3 hours ago, Glaran K'erman said:

Imagine if SQUAD built their own engine and we never had to say the word 'Unity' again...dreams.

Nice dream, but some of the issues (eg wheels) aren't even unity, they're physx inherited into unity and then into ksp.

@tater Stock bug fixes by Claw and the Landing Gear patches by @GoSlash27 eliminate 99% of the problems people had with KSP 1.1.2

The people on fire are either the ones who didn't install these fixes or they're Linux players.

16 minutes ago, Enceos said:

@tater Stock bug fixes by Claw and the Landing Gear patches by @GoSlash27 eliminate 99% of the problems people had with KSP 1.1.2

The people on fire are either the ones who didn't install these fixes or they're Linux players.

Or average Joe gamer, who doesn't mod games or post on the KSP forums.

1 minute ago, klgraham1013 said:

Or average Joe gamer, who doesn't mod games or post on the KSP forums.

Well they'd fall into bracket one, wouldn't they. @Enceos is right on. The gears are a pain when they don't work, but they're actually not unplayably bad - I've taken off in planes, flown and landed safely about 20 times this week in various planes with various gear configs. Mostly it's been a case of understanding how and when a gear was overloaded, which frankly is just design process - you know, that part of KSP u do before u get to fly around.

Or they are using wheels/legs/gear in situations which in particular the landing gear patches posted make worse rather than better (everything is a tradeoff).

 

All I can say is that while we have acknowledged, and will continue to acknowledge, the issues with wheels/legs/gear, and in particular the issues surrounding having to force-disable wheels in close proximity to other objects (in order to prevent phantom physics kicks do to a Unity bug, as Arsonide explained), it does remain possible to use the wheels, legs, and gear. For example I spent the last week of my vacation building airplanes for Go For Launch and have been able to take off and land every plane successfully. Also a few planes I converted over from 1.0.5 (that used Baha's Adjustable Gear, man I miss that). I have had to tweak the friction a couple times, and I did have to have an annoyingly placed tailwheel (but that's as much about not having a small enough landing gear as the 'wheel disabled' issue). In addition I have made a fair few test rovers in stock KSP and got them to perform OK, and landed a bunch of test craft on legs.

What's the takeaway here? Yes, there are problems, some due to Unity bugs, some due to VPP bugs, some due to our bugs (gasp! But no really, we've never claimed we're bugless), and some due to use case. I'm well aware I'm a realism junkie, but sanely low speeds and low sink rates work soooo much better.

EDIT: To be clear, that doesn't mean we're not looking into how to make more use cases survivable. We are. All I am saying is that yes, for some of us it is playable.

8 minutes ago, NathanKell said:

Also a few planes I converted over from 1.0.5 (that used Baha's Adjustable Gear, man I miss that).

A lot of us miss that. Last few days I was able to create some planes after long time. Only with one plane have issues with landing. Fliping over on touching ground, bouncing rear placed gear too much, etc. While stock gears have issues of it's own, it also revealed design flaws on that craft that I was not aware that even exist. Most of this planes share similar design look and only one plane out of 20 encountered issue. I'm close to solution how to solve even that one.

Without availability of adjutable landing gears, there is noticable gap with various leg sizes between stock gears. For example, if you put small landing gear in front, on light weight planes small landing gear would be enough (weight support size etc.), but you can't use it because it will not touch ground when you need to place it on wings. There is also oposite way. Sometimes you need heavy duty gear with short leg, so you can place it just below COM, on hull, to support most of weight, but you can't use existing gears because their legs are too long for that.

What will possibly cover most of design needs is that each landing gear comes with two leg length variations. When you put landing gear with shorter leg in front, at the bottom of hull and long leg variant on rear, attached at the middle of hull, on sides, whole craft should be leveled.

With exception of heavy lending gear, there is also need of short leg variant that have same (or close) leg length as smallest landing gear.
That will cover a wide craft design needs, even without adjustable landing gear needs.

Other thing that I noticed is need of longer suspension motion. (Difference in leg length when is fully compressed under craft weight and when you take off and landing gear is ion air). That is needed to have visual representation in game is spring is too stiff or too soft.
Speaking of that, spring can have bigger difference between softest and stiffest force on all landing gears, so you can batter adjust those per craft design.

Just quick notes that I was able to notice in short time. Sorry, I was a bit off topic for this thread, but needed to say that before I forget about it.

1 hour ago, Enceos said:

@tater Stock bug fixes by Claw and the Landing Gear patches by @GoSlash27 eliminate 99% of the problems people had with KSP 1.1.2

The people on fire are either the ones who didn't install these fixes or they're Linux players.

I have stock bug fixes installed, and the landing gear fix doesn't include legs that I can tell. My legs still explode if I touch them on EVA. If the two of them (Claw/Slashy)could fix things so quickly, it never should have left prerelease unfixed.

1 hour ago, NathanKell said:

Or they are using wheels/legs/gear in situations which in particular the landing gear patches posted make worse rather than better (everything is a tradeoff).

I'm using any of the 3 stock landing legs attached to simple landers (mk1 landercan with a fuel tank, engine, and legs). Touch it on EVA, BOOM, every single time (orbit or walking in low gravity---possible on Kerbin, but you have to try more, vs not try at all).

Edited May 26, 2016 by tater

15 minutes ago, tater said:

I'm using any of the 3 stock landing legs attached to simple landers (mk1 landercan with a fuel tank, engine, and legs). Touch it on EVA, BOOM, every single time (orbit or walking in low gravity---possible on Kerbin, but you have to try more, vs not try at all).

Not to sound like Groucho Marx's doctor or anything, but have you tried not touching the landing gear while on EVA?

I don't think anybody (least of all NathanKell) is arguing that that's expected, normal, or even acceptable. What's being argued is that it is in fact possible to play the game and use landing gear, if you just exercise a little care.

@tater I must say I was a little surprised by the following statement you made.

2 hours ago, tater said:

Sorry, but if the current unity version is incompatible with landing a spacecraft (I don't ever use aircraft/spaceplanes, but for those people it sounds worse than my legged landers), then 1.1.2 should be "pre-release" and not released until that is fixed.

I've made several planes since 1.1.2, one of which is a 2 crew, 12 passenger, SSTO shuttle that runs tourists up into orbit for lots of cash and reputation.  I'm not even sure how many times I've taken off and landed this plane, but I know it is in the dozens, and I have never had a crash or other problem with the plane or its wheels.

I do think that the wheels seem to need a bit more stiffness and damping, but they work fine for me just adjusting the values to the maximum using the existing sliders.  I think the wheel configuration could also do with accepting a wider range of values for stiffness and damping.

The exception for me seems to be the smallest gear, in particular the nose gear (I think its the LY-01), which seems to always veer off the runway for me no matter how I configure it.

7 hours ago, NathanKell said:

1.1.3 will include those fixes we can do in a reasonable timeframe (i.e. that will not unreasonably delay the engine update that will do more fixes) and without prejudicing said update (i.e. doing tons of work we'd just have to rip out). 1.2 is first and foremost a Unity upgrade that should offer better hardware and OS support/fixes (i.e. less crashing) and better wheels/legs/etc support/fixes. Beyond that come any new (or partially-new) features.

Thanks for this clarifier  I think a lot of us had the impression that 1.2 was new features. As long as the devs appreciate that the current version's issues really are quite serious and need to take priority, I think we're all happy with however long that requires

*edit* It's not that we aren't excited for new content, because we are. But when a significant portion of people are having big issues just getting the game to not CTD, or are unable to reliably do the things they used to do in previous versions, it becomes very hard for us to see beyond those issues. Talking about content updates at this point becomes quite worrying, because content implies delays, during which none of the affected people can get their crack KSP hit. So, yeah, thanks for the reassurance that the main goal of 1.1.3 and 1.2 both will be bug fixes. We're looking forward to those, and as soon as we're a crowd of happy campers again, we'll be all abuzz for new features  

Edited May 26, 2016 by eddiew

Is there any chance of sneaking angle snap as a docking port tweakable into 1.1.3 because

(a) that would be awesome

and

(b) watching EJ do the angry gibbon about it would be capital h Hilarious

Mostly (b), what can I say.

13 hours ago, JJE64 said:

Were it me, I wouldn't release until I had a finished product.

If by "finished product", you mean no bugs at all and everything working absolutely perfectly, I suspect you'd end up never releasing your product at all.  And even if you did manage to get that far, the first time you try to add any new features, it's just going to add more bugs along with it. 

Admittedly, a couple of the bugs in this version are more serious than most and they shouldn't have released it until they were fixed(nor should they have released and then had the whole company go on vacation for almost a month), but it's a bit too late for that now.  But reality is that products like this will never be completely finished and sooner or later, they'll be under a huge amount of pressure to release SOMETHING even if it's not perfect. 

They obviously know that there are things which need to be fixed and they know what those things are, so at this point all we can do is actually give them the time needed to do so.  And also worth noting that a lot of times, the people working on bugfixing will be different than the ones working on NEW features, so adding new stuff(especially if it was close to being ready anyway) might not make it take any longer to fix the existing problems.  If there IS a conflict between the two, then sure...fix the bugs first.  But if it is possible to do both together, then they might as well.

On 5/26/2016 at 0:52 AM, tater said:

I have stock bug fixes installed, and the landing gear fix doesn't include legs that I can tell. My legs still explode if I touch them on EVA. If the two of them (Claw/Slashy)could fix things so quickly, it never should have left prerelease unfixed.

I'm using any of the 3 stock landing legs attached to simple landers (mk1 landercan with a fuel tank, engine, and legs). Touch it on EVA, BOOM, every single time (orbit or walking in low gravity---possible on Kerbin, but you have to try more, vs not try at all).

 

On 5/26/2016 at 1:10 AM, 5thHorseman said:

Not to sound like Groucho Marx's doctor or anything, but have you tried not touching the landing gear while on EVA?

I don't think anybody (least of all NathanKell) is arguing that that's expected, normal, or even acceptable. What's being argued is that it is in fact possible to play the game and use landing gear, if you just exercise a little care.

I haven't tried to get out and touch the landing legs with a kerbal but any time any of the legs touch the surface of any body. The craft blows up. On old and new craft.

I landed on rover wheels then deployed the landing legs and it explodes. I tried to  deploy the gear before landing 1 time and it must have hit another part and exploded in flight.

 

I did some testing with all 3 landing legs on the runway and every time it will explode no matter what I do.

I looked at the craft files for all 3 legs. I noticed the LT5 legs cost more than the LT2. In game the LT2 are larger and would cost more.

 

Also the LT2 has 2 lines for brake torque and the LT5 and LT1 do not. The LT2 is the large landing *LEG* not *GEAR WHEELS*

Comparing some of the older files that work I see some differences in things like cost http://prntscr.com/b8kzed

and a few other differences that either didn't carry over or different between the 2 http://prntscr.com/b8l651

Updated the mods 1 at a time and still nothing. http://prntscr.com/b8l651

Edited May 28, 2016 by LTL King
